title: Mosaic Z endstop support.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After about two months of owning a MakerGear Mosaic, I had only one small issue. The guide rod that the Z-endstop is attached to could rotate freely, causing the endstop switch to move out of place with the vibrations of the printer. 
This is a simple modification to the original Z-endstop that ships with the Mosaic to keep the guide rod from rotating.

This can either be printed as a support that fits between the switch and the existing endstop, or as an entire endstop (which I have not yet tried). I recommed the first option, as the support can be installed without much disassembly. To install the support:
1. Print 'mosaic-z-enstop-mod-support.stl'.
2. Unscrew and remove switch assembly from the ensdstop. The LED should pop right out with a push from below.
3. Unsolder wires from switch (don't forget where they go!), place switch on support and rewire the switch through the slot (see picture).
4. Screw switch and support to endstop, replacing LED in it's hole. If you feel the need to have the modified endstop as a single piece you can try printing 'mosaic-z-enstop-mod-endstop.stl'. I haven't printed it yet, but support material will certainly be required. You'll then probably need to take the printer apart a ways to install it. Also included is the OpenSCAD file that generated both stls, as well as the original Z-endtop file I got from here:
https://github.com/MakerGear/Mosaic
Thanks MakerGear!

title: 3d Printer End Stop Made from Scratch

description.text:
I needed end stops for my printer and, since it's always more fun to make than to buy, this Thing is what I came up with.

I wanted a single design flexible enough that I can use for all six end stops, and I wanted it to be somewhat adjustable in both the mount and the trigger point. The STL files here make three different parts: the end stop itself and two mounts, one designed for horizontal and one for vertical use. A single openSCAD source file codes all three - there are selector variables at the top enabling you to choose what to print. As uploaded, it will make the end stop and both holders i.e., contents of all three STL files.

Source file also contains the same instructions as are listed in this Thing, but obviously no pictures!

There are a plethora of end stop designs on Thingiverse already, most of them simpler than this. I still hope people might find this design useful.

To make this end stop, you will need (see picture above):

printed parts
a piece of spring (i cut mine from a 3/8" inner diameter spring #150 from ACE Hardware)
M3 screw, 12-20mm long
M3 nut
a small piece of aluminum foil
28Ga or similar wire to connect the switch to your printer

The switch is reasonably accurate in the sense it will trigger at the same point every time, but it's not quite accurate enough to calibrate the Z print dimension. There is a fraction of millimeter noise, enough to mess up the first layer print adhesion. I use the vertical stop to protect the printer, but use a force-sensitive resistor to accurately calibrate my Z-axis. See
https://www.instructables.com/id/Homing-a-3D-Printer-Using-Force-sensitive-Resistor/ for the gory details.

I make no restrictions on use of this code, feel free to use, modify, share, etc. as you like.

Printer:

Configurable Fab Machine homebuilt

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed this in PLA, using a heated bed, 0.2mm layer height, 0.4mm nozzle. I would expect that ABS would also work well. The clasps to close the end stop body and to retain the end stop in a holder need to be printed from somewhat elastic material - "somewhat" being a loose criterion since PLA is not that elastic and still worked well.

There are a number of tiny parts, so make sure your print adhesion to the bed is good, or print with a skirt. Skirt, though, is finicky to remove on small parts. I printed on a borosilicate glass bed smeared with a thin layer of Elmer's glue and had no problems with adhesion.

Strip a couple of centimeters of insulation from the wires on the end that goes into the switch. Thread the M3 screw through the base block and wrap the stripped end of the wire around it. Tighten the M3 nut to hold the wire in place. You can back off the screw as you need once the switch is assembled. Put the bottom washer (the one with M3 hole) on top to hold the spring and insulate it from the screw and washer. Thread the second wire through the top washer (one with small hole). Wrap the wired top washer in aluminum foil. Keep in mind that this washer slides in the switch body, so don't overdo the amount of foil. Insert the plunger into the switch body. Insert the top washer - the same orientation as shown on preceding pictures. Curve the wire in a full turn or so around the perimeter so it flexes when the plunger is depressed and the washer moves. Cut the spring to length and insert into the switch. Once the base is installed, the wire should go through the wire cutout in the base. The wire cutout should be on one of the two switch sides that do not have holes for the clasps. Base is installed and one of the retainers is in. The hooked part of the retainer goes into the base, then the other side is inserted into the hole in the switch body. Fully assembled switch. Assebled switch base. Note how the wire passthrough has to be orthogonal to the retaining clips. Switch inserted into a vertical holder. The retaining clip will go into the rectangular hole. Fully assembled vertical holder. In practice, the holder would be mounted first and the switch then inserted into the holder - once the switch is in, there is no way to tighten the mounting screw. End stop mounted on my printer. Note the, ah, elegant wire routing - very much a work in progress! End stop with the gantry close to the Z position where the switch would trigger. Final adjustments

Both holders are meant to be attached using M4 or similar screws. The mount holes allow some leeway in positioning. I found the switch is somewhat prone to sticking if there is a great amount of travel, so you should shoot for least travel that works for your mounting location. The M3 screw can usually be replaced without disassembling the switch if you need a different length. It's fine to have the screw not tightened i.e., backed out of the switch body, to get the right trigger point.

The switch body could be shorter, but I found that a bit longer spring works better. You can print a shorter plunger, though.

So there you have it. A bit Rube Goldbergish for sure, but it did what I need it to do.

title: RecTec Mini - Pellet Hopper Extension (WORK IN PROGRESS!!)

description.text:
NOTE: I HAVE NOT YET PRINTED THIS TO TEST THE FIT!!

I got my RecTec Mini a few weeks ago, and it's been great so far. My first long cook, I ran out of pellets ahead of schedule. Luckily my Maverick thermometer alerted me once it dropped low enough temp.

I got to thinking, the hopper should be pretty easy to modify. I've made up an adapter plate, which I can put an 8" duct or duct reducer on it. This way, I can put a few more cubic feet of pellets on when I want.

title: NS1 Muzzle Brake for Nerf N Strike Blasters

description.text:
*Update**
I have now tested both versions on several different blasters. Nearly every blasters N- Strike muzzle has different dimensions. Version 2 will work for the Recon MK II, and the Retaliator. The first version seems to work better for the Stryfe and Rapidstrike. I tried both of the versions on the Zombie strike Longshot, neither of them fit because the tolerances were way to tight. I will test them on more blasters as I get my hands on them.

  • I have added a version 2. This version has slightly looser tolerances and wont be as tight. I have noticed not all blasters have the same dimensions on their muzzle. This version should fit most if not all blasters and still have enough friction to fit snuggly.

This is a muzzle brake that is designed to fit the N Strike attachment point on Nerf N Strike blasters. I have printed them anywhere from 20% infill to 100% infill. I also use 4 shells on all sides to ensure the part is strong and has maximum coverage. If there are any problems let me know in the comments.

No

description.text:
This is a remote controlled gripper used on a custom radio controlled boat. It is specifically designed to work with model buoys that are also posted in Thingiverse.

The arms are moved by a standard servo motor. A servo drive gear moves the driven arm gear.

The grippers are printed with ABS as a rigid material and Ninja Flex for the gripper portion. It can be printed and used without the flex portion.

4mm s/s nuts and bolts are used to hold things together and as pivot points for the arms and gears.

The bottom of the gear assembly is made in two parts. The "GripAsmBotBot" is customized to bit the bow of the model boat. You'll need to modify this for your particular

Many of the designs I found was bulky and didn't have a drain when mounted in this orientation. I wanted it this way so the plug dries at a natural angle if wet inside. It is minimalistic on the wall.

I created this so the plug isn't a snug fit so it doesn't wear on the plastic like many others. This does make it fall out easier if you move around on the cable so scale it down slightly if you want it to hold the plug with some force.

I was fascinated by the ability of these epoxy mixing tubes to, in a very short amount of space, completely mix two disparate fluids. Here is the principle of how it works, at each junction the flow is divided in half. Divide it in half 20 times and you've divided the flow a million times.

Use this as a model for anything you need to mix up really well.

print_settings.Notes:: For the TEN & FIVE cell, there are TR (top row) and LR (lower row).

description.text:
I've wanted to build a larger word clock for a while and finally decided to build one that doesn't have to be printed in one piece. To keep it simple I also didn't put in all the letters that are common to many word clocks.

I used a partial strip of WS2812B's (Neopixels, 60 pixels per metre) run by a Wemos D1 as an NTP client. But really once the display face is constructed any number of micro controllers can be used to run the display. Like an Arduino, ESP8266, with RTC, NTP, GPS, you name it.

Dec 15, 2017 - added Arduino sketch for Wemos. Requires a photo resistor to handle auto dimming or you can comment that section of the code out.

Change the sketch for your own time zone rule and NTP time server.

Printer:

Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

36%

Notes:

I used black PLA, 3 layers for the bottom to stop any light from coming through.

I tested transparent PLA for the lens but found that I could easily see the neopixels in the cells. Thus white with no more that two layers worked the best. This still lets ample light come through, but diffuses the LED's enough to give a more or less even lighting.

For the white PLA lens parts, I resized the master face in Slic3r (X only dimension) to fit in the cell, printed it, resized, repeated for the 22 cells of the clock. It doesn't take long to print a lens so this goes fairly quick.

For the TEN & FIVE cell, there are TR (top row) and LR (lower row).

Assembly

I had no idea how rigid the whole cell structure would be after printing, but I was pleasantly surprised as I assembled it. It's very well held together.

I used M3 x 5 for the internal cell to cell joints. Where the cells meet I drilled with a 3mm bit, on the adjacent cell I drilled with a 2.5mm bit. It worked far better than I expected.

For the frame sides M3 x 6. I drilled out the frame brackets with 3mm bit, the ends of the cells with the 2.5mm bit.

For the white lens in each cell, they can be a press fit, or very thin double sided transparent 3M tape will hold them in.

The letters like O, Q, R, A have small pieces so I used 3M transparent tape to hold the pieces on the white lens.

As I was installing the white lens pieces I found they worked better if the smooth side of the print was inside the cell. I.e. so the top layer of the print was the textured layer and the one exposed in the cells.

To hold the Neopixels, I used a standard piece of 5mm foam board. Cut the Neopixels into strips, stuck them on the foam board, used solid core wire to jumper from one strip to the next. I used 112 Neopixels. There are slots in the cells where the pixels run.

title: Drawing Robot - Arduino Uno + CNC Shield + GRBL

description.text:
This drawing robot is similar to the commercially available AxiDraw. It is powered by an Arduino Uno controller and a CNC Shield which uses GRBL firmware. Approximate cost to build this drawing robot is $100.

Documentation can be found here and by an attached PDF thanks to Jonathan K.
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1GihJuR7yHVtUPYCp9GVDHLsJUhT2RwPrkIopzYrXYhw/edit?usp=sharing

This robot was put together using two other people's designs. I added the improved pen slider and the controller enclosure. This drawing robot allows you to draw things in Inkscape and then plot them out. The drawing robot receives G Code commands that are created inside an Inkscape extension. Below are the links to the software I used. I now suggest using the Inkscape MI GRBL Extension. There's an attached document explaining how to use the software.

When setting up your hardware you must do the following:

  1. Be sure to install 3 jumpers on the CNC Shield for each stepper driver. I have added a photo showing the jumpers.
  2. You must use the GRBL version pointed to in the link below. Replace the "config.h" file with the one I provide which has the correct features enabled before you compile and download from the Arduino IDE.
  3. Set the GRBL parameters to the settings that I provide in one of the photos. This step is missing from the otherwise excellent instructions. You must do this or the robot will not work.

I have posted all the parts needed from the two source designs. There are only 15 parts to print and none of them are very large. I added a stronger pen slider and a controller enclosure. I also clarified the names that were in Spanish. I have posted all needed files so that there isn't confusion regarding which parts are needed from each of the original designs.

My drawing robot is modified version of this one
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2058866

Place this version of GRBL Firmware for the Arduino on your computer. You must use this version of GRBL. Other GRBL versions do not have the control code for the Z axis servo.
https://github.com/robottini/grbl-servo

Replace the default config.h file in GRBL with the one I supply in the "Thing Files" section

Upload GRBL to your Arduino Uno using these instructions
https://github.com/grbl/grbl/wiki/Compiling-Grbl (Ignore references to GRBL V1.1)
You must copy the config.h which I supply here to the directory where GRBL resides and then do the upload. The new config.h will be used for the compile of the GRBL code.

Inkscape Drawing Software
https://inkscape.org/en/

Universal G-Code Sender
https://winder.github.io/ugs_website/download/

Use the MI Extension to generate G Code:
http://www.mediafire.com/file/ae0wquqornzc3o2/MI+Inkscape+Extension.zip
There is a tutorial in the Files section on how to use the software.

HARDWARE
2x Nema 17
2x Linear rod M8 x 450mm, X Axis
2x Linear rod M8 x 350mm, Y axis
2x Linear rod M3 x 75mm, Z Axis
(You can find them in any old CDROM or purchase on EBay)
1x M8x470mm threaded rod
8x LM8UU or printed
1x Servo sg90
2x GT2 Pulley 16 teeth
5x Bearing 624zz
1x 2000mm GT2 belt

misc M3 and M4 screws and nuts
M8 nuts

Electronics
Arduino Uno
CNC Shield
12V 2A Wall Transformer
https://www.amazon.com search for "B019Q3U72M"
2-4 limit switches ( optional. Suggest to leave them off and add later if you want them)

Software
Inkscape which is the graphics design software
Inkscape MI GRBL Extension
Universal G Code Sender (sends the machine commands from a file)
GRBL which is the Arduino firmware (programmed into the Arduino Uno)

I have supplied a few G Code files that work with this drawing robot. If your drawing robot is identical to this design, the G Code files should also work with yours.

Here are two videos
https://youtu.be/kpTIFBDcTaY
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QuQ75pbHqXc

Update 6-15-2017: I added the limit switches about 10 days ago and they don't add much to the functionality. When GRBL sees a limit switch hit, it just stops with an alarm condition. You must soft reset the robot and your drawing cannot be continued. The homing feature doesn't seem to work. I read in another persons post that they could not get home to work in GRBL 0.9. At this point I suggest building the drawing robot without the limit switches. As long as your drawing does not exceed the envelope of the robot, you won't need the limit switches.

Update 6-19-2017: My friend found a better Inkscape Extension for generating G Code.
I think the MI Extension is easier to use and generates better G Code:
http://www.mediafire.com/file/ae0wquqornzc3o2/MI+Inkscape+Extension.zip

Update 6-26-2017: I added the config.h file needed for GRBL for this machine. With this file and the GRBL parameter settings in the screen shot, you should be able to easily get your machine up and running. Don't forget to install the stepper driver jumpers.

Update 7-4-2017:
The top and bottom clam shells did not fit without pushing the LM8UU bearings slightly out of alignment. I removed a small amount of material from the top clamshell to allow clearance for the bottom clamshell posts. The old Top_XY_clamshell.stl file has been removed and replaced with the Top_XY_clamshell_V4.stl file. Thanks to rocketmannate who caught this problem.

Update 11-18-2017
Jonathan K. provided assembly documentation. Thanks you so much. I appreciate your efforts. Checkout the great PDF with excellent photos.

Update 3-11-2018
I'm getting many questions from people that claim their drawing robot doesn't work. Please review all the steps in the description. If your robot doesn't work, you probably have the wrong version of GRBL, did not copy the config.h file, forgot the CNC jumpers, or failed to setup the GRBL parameters. If your Z axis motor isn't working, make sure you have the correct version of GRBL and that you wired your servo to the correct pins.

Update 3-25-2018
I created a new document that explains how to install Inkscape, the MI extension, and the Universal G-Code Sender. It also guides you through a couple of Inkscape projects.

comments.text: I added the limit switches and they don't add much to the functionality. When GRBL sees a limit switch hit, it just stops with an alarm condition. You must soft reset the robot and your drawing cannot be continued. The homing feature doesn't seem to work either. I read in another persons post that they could not get home to work in GRBL 0.9. At this point I suggest building the drawing robot without the limit switches. As long as your drawing does not exceed the envelope of the robot, you won't need the limit switches.

comments.text: Sounds like you are doing fine. There are two things that set the configuration. The config.h file which you have swapped. You also need to set the parameters which the G-Code Sender (Either Source Rabbit or Universal) allow you to set. I provided the screen shot with the parameters. Basically the config.h sets the behavior such as the fact that this is a CoreXY machine and the parameters set things like the number of stepper steps for a millimeter. Also: Be sure to install 3 jumpers on the CNC Shield for each stepper driver.

comments.text: I'm interested in building this. I was wondering if 20 toothed pulleys would work or if there's an important reason for 16 teeth.
comments.author: Haryeti

comments.text: 20 tooth pulleys will work. You will have to adjust the X/Y step mm in the configuration. See the GRBL controller settings. Once you get the drawing robot together, direct the X axis to move 100 mm. Measure it and you will probably find that it moves 125 mm because 20 teeth are 25% more than 16 teeth.  Entering 160 instead of 200 for the steps per mm should compensate for the difference in pulleys.
comments.author: Haryeti

comments.text: Did anyone else have problems with the clamshell parts? The LM8UUs don't really fit in it, and the two halves of the clamshell don't line up. With a bit of force, I was able to get the bearings in, and get the clamshell together, but then the bearings wouldn't line up, and the rods were binding badly. I know that my printer is properly calibrated, as I use it for mechanical parts on a regular basis.
comments.author: rocketmannate

comments.text: Yes, I had some minor problems. I took a Dremel tool and opened the area where the posts on the bottom of the clam shell line up with the holes on the top of the clam shell. This keeps  the bearings from being pushed out of alignment. I only had to remove a small amount of material.

author: JoshuaShaw

title: Boeing Insitu Scaneagle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Print at this scale and it'll have about 12 inch wing span.

Made this for a commission, but they ended up not wanting it. So here it is for you guys/gals. This it the Boeing Scaneagle. It's a catapult launched drone. More information can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Insitu_ScanEagle.

The stand is brand new, never been printed. I imagine there might be some issues that arise from the pointy parts. The aircraft has also never been printed for that matter... so please let me know if you have any issues printing them. I have done some preliminary scaling of the wing socket joints, and the stand, so hopefully there's no issues there. Everything else should have ample recesses.

I try to design for minimal support, but I'm not sure what support will be required.

Thanks for checking out the download. If you enjoy the model and would be so kind to support me monatarily for my work please consider supporting here: https://www.patreon.com/oranhunter

remixed_from.author: Bogdan87
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for MP Select Mini

description.text:
Upgraded to Octopi to run my Makerbot Replicator 2 and had the camera taped to my Replicator 2 for about a year now. It was so close that I had to use a wide angle lens to see the prints. I looked around for a camera mount and couldn't find one that just worked. So I just started looking for any raspberry pi camera arm design that I could use for my needs. I found the one by Bogdan87 and it was really good. I printed it out and just holding it in place I saw that I needed to up just above my top rail for good placement. I didn't want to screw anything into the front of my printer, so I designed a little adapter that I could screw the arm onto the front, and it would just wrap around the top rail and hold itself in place. I can now slide the camera back and forth and angle it as needed. And I still have the wide angle lens I can clip on to see the entire print bed for large prints. :D

I also designed a second openscad file that included the mount from the other design as part of the print, while cutting out even more stuff for when I put a top on the printer. You have to put your path to the mount from the other design for it to render, but I included the finished stl to use as is. It might or might not need some support when you print it, I haven't tried it yet.

comments.text:
MrEDJay,
The tolerances are tight, the threads are done to spec from solidworks. I did successfully print on my Prusa i3 Mk2s in PLA as modeled. As for the threads jamming, tighten to press, the unscrew the actual press before trying to remove the cap. It's really designed with the idea of making "pellets" as opposed to what you mentioned, however, I did notice in field testing that it is very important to release the press screw before removing the cap.
comments.author: btolson

comments.text:
Printed it out, One thing I can say is that the tolerances are incredibly tight my friend. Try incorporating some built in offsets in order to get a good grip, but also work straight out of the gate. I think with a little tweaking this would be a great little press. I actually used this to press some shake and press into rosin.
Worked great. I think that my hands are a little too big for this one at it's current size though :( I tightened it up as much as I could, and then found out that it was having trouble backing out of the threads because well...I didn't do enough post processing. After a little while with the pliers, I got it free.
So make sure you do enough post processing before you press any pollen lol.

comments.author: dangerweenie

comments.text: thanks - it might help to bevel/chamfer the edges of the tamper cylinders.
comments.author: Cibonacci

comments.text: I used S3D. Now I uploaded a new press with a less diameter of 7 mm instead of 7,6 mm . I printed it and it worked well :) The other part is still working for me and the capsules i have.
comments.author: dangerweenie

comments.text: just printed the updated tamper - works great! would probably benefit from being a bit longer to push the powder down further, but it gets the job done.  thanks!
comments.author: Cibonacci

comments.text: thanks, im going to try tonight!  i will keep you posted.
comments.author: Cibonacci

author: www_adonis_com

description.text:
Edit 5/28/17 : I missed uploading part 1 and 2. They are there now. Sorry.

This is the Thor Ragnarok Helmet with the wing rotator bar. The helmet was slightly modified to use the rotator bar. The previous version helmet will not work with these wings.

Part 16 might be too big for your print bed. If this part is too big just print parts 20 and 22 instead. part 20 and 22 is part 16 split in two.

This helmet is was sized for an adult male but check dimensions on pdf file. units are in millimeters.

comments.text:
Probably a ridiculous request, but - would you be willing to rework this as two pieces for those of us who have insanely large format printers?
or, for someone who is starting at this, how hard would that be for me to do?
comments.author: Lunar_Engineer

comments.text: That looks gorgious, and I'd love to get rid of the helment I'm using now. (and the shin armour, and Mjolnir, and the chest armour plates...)
comments.author: Lunar_Engineer

comments.text: Did anyone else notice that part 6 is larger that the rest of the files?  At 100% scaling on both parts, part 12 which is the mirror half is (in millimeters) x:173.231 y:67.94 z:89.819  but part 6 is x:159.093 y:51.175 z:104.396
comments.author: jinxerfelix

comments.text: This helmet is incredible...
comments.author: KingMura

comments.text: Hi there. have U or anyone else printed the whole helmet, minus the wings?
comments.author: Digggrrr

comments.text: I have not
comments.author: Digggrrr

comments.text: man getting all these pieces to line up is a pain lol
comments.author: Christherock23

comments.text: This is probably a total noob question but what part of my head am i supposed to measure to figure out the scale of this thing? im pretty big headed and have a hard time finding hats that fit me but ive never printed out a helmet for myself lol
comments.author: Christherock23

comments.text: Printed and assembled everything. First off thank you so much for this model it turned out better than i could've hoped for. i'm having trouble with the wings and rotator bar. How do you keep it attached to the helmet. There doesnt appear to be enough tension to keep the wings pinned on the nubs on the main helmet and they fall off. i was thinking of using rare earth magnets to hold them in place but was wondering what you'd recommend.
comments.author: bbonner

comments.text: I printed the helmet that can not rotate the wings and just glued it on.  I was also thinking magnets would be the way to go with this.
comments.author: bbonner

comments.text: I was not going to do it because of the cost but I just may have to buy some steel fill pla and print this man, you are awesome!
comments.author: SSgtFig

comments.text: What infill percentage and wall thicknesses would you recommend for this helmet
comments.author: Minh_132

comments.text: I printed it at 15% infill and 2 wall thickness.
comments.author: Minh_132

comments.text: Can you add a file that has the two parts as one part  thankyou
comments.author: Killonious

comments.text: I'm not sure what you are asking.
comments.author: Minh_132

comments.text: and can you post the pictures of the helmet in real life and it on. i just want to see how it looks being worn and how it fits
comments.author: Killonious

comments.text: Sorry I not longer have the helmet.  It was a a gift.
comments.author: Minh_132

comments.text: whats the wall thickness of it in mm
comments.author: Killonious

comments.text: the wall thickness is 3 mm.
comments.author: Minh_132

comments.text: Keep up the good work man your a beast! I appreciate you sharing your work!!
comments.author: Telli

comments.text: No problem. I'm glad you are enjoying the designs.
comments.author: Telli

comments.text: Hello, I am aving problem with part 13. I go to slice it, but with no succes. Maybe the file is broken?
comments.author: manovello

comments.text: I'm sorry to hear that. I have printed the helmet and had no issues.  I checked part 13 and see nothing wrong with it.
comments.author: manovello

comments.text: Currently on printing part 4 of this helmet. Part two messed up a tiny bit in the corner but I am thinking it could easily be repaired. Since I am a total noob to all this would someone mind giving me some pointers. Once all is printed (fingers crossed it all goes well) what do kind of adhesive do you guys use to assemble this? I appreciate any and all help.
comments.author: kperez2309

comments.text: It's depends on the plastic you are using. For PLA I use locite super  glue. For ABS. I make an ABS slurry.
comments.author: kperez2309

comments.text: Is that better than E6000? I am using PLA. Would I have to sand in order to spray paint or will using a primer prior be ok? I was really nervous about printing part 5 but but it came out great! so far everything is working out well. Thanks so much for this design. Please keep the pointers coming. Any help is greatly appreciated!
comments.author: Killonious

comments.text: I am also really having a tough time with piece 20 and 22. Ive tried many rotations and no luck :/ Literally the last piece I need and Im ready to assemble! Any luck on a possible fix?
comments.author: RagingBeard

comments.text: What exactly are you having problems with?  It's not sticking to build plate?
comments.author: RagingBeard

comments.text: yeah the edge that is shown in with side fin (not the swivel bar that goes around helmet) printing without support it fails to print properly. printing with auto created supports same thing. Tried using custom supports underneath and still fails. Also tried many rotations but even with support underneath its failing and im not sure why. Had zero issues with any other part through out the helmet.
comments.author: Killonious

comments.text: That is weird.  I'm looking at part 20 in simplify 3D and the fin side does not need a support  at the bottom.  Only the bar needs a support at the bottom.  Unfortunately I have only printed the helmet part so far and my print is down so i can not print that part to see what is happening.  Once my replacement parts come in I will try to print that part.
comments.author: RagingBeard

comments.text: Is there a way to describe the circumference of the helmet?
comments.author: kanuci14

comments.text: I have printed this helmet at 100% scale and it fit my head.  I am a male adult over 6 feet tall.  There are some dimensions in the pdf file.
comments.author: kanuci14

comments.text: I looked at the pdf and looked at the dimensions. Are the dimensions measured by centimeters, millimeters, inches, or something else? I am also over feet tall however, my head is about 25.5 inches around, so I just wanted to see what this helmets base measurements are.
comments.author: Killonious

comments.text: The units are in millimeters.  My head is about 26 inches and it fits me at 100% scale when I printed it so you should be fine.  It was just big enough to put a little padding on the top.
comments.author: kanuci14

comments.text: Wish me luck, I'm going for an all at once print, I'm thinking it will be at least 50 hours. S3D says 48 hours, but I usually have to add an additional 10-20% printing time.

description.text:
(to tweak the dimensions of this model click on the Open In Customizer button, adjust as needed and saved the modified design)

Use this thing for safe disposal of X-Acto blades. Simply insert your used blades through the slot and when the bank gets full, close the slot with an adhesive tape, dispose it and print a new and empty bank.

The model has an internal guard that makes it difficult (but not impossible) to remove blades through the slot. If you want extra protection, pause the printing half way, throw in a small magnet (see picture, they are available on ebay and from many other sources) and continue the printing. This will keep the blades clamped to each other within the bank.

The model is oriented in printing position (with the slot at the bottom). When done printing, flip it over to expose the slot at the top.

I printed with PLA, 70C bed, 200C nozzle, cooling fan, 3 layers bottom, top and shell, 15% infill.

print_settings.Notes:: 3 shells with top and bottom at 1mm. No supports needed if printed at full size, when I scaled it down for a test print of her head and used a lower resolution (thicker layers) her nose didn't turn out too well. Otherwise everything else prints fine with no supports on my printer.

description.text:
I love the Pop Buddha and it's one of the first things I printed when I got my printer. I also loved that it was supplied with a headless Buddha, so as I found myself learning mesh editors, I wanted to make something interesting with the headless Buddha. While I've got a couple ideas, this is the first one that I've managed to successfully finish. I love the delicate beauty of the sculpture of Sappho, and just love the juxtaposition of her head with the big Buddha body.

I made this with MeshMixer, and it should be a nice, clean, non-manifold model that prints well. I made a test print to see if she'd print without supports, and the tip of her nose was a little rough, but when I printed the entire thing at full scale, the results were just fine with no supports at all.

I made and evaluated several hubs.

Type-A:
One side is a ball bearing and the other is a friction bearing.
It turns lightly, but the filament does not loosen.
It is good performance.

The M6 screw rod was used for the shaft.

The ball bearing is made of polyacetal and has an
outer diameter of 26 mm, an inner diameter of 6 mm and a thickness of 7 mm.

Type-B:
The M8 screw rod was used for the shaft.
It was attached to JGAURORA A3.

The hub is turning directly on the M8 threaded rod.
Concerned about wear.

Both types A and B conform to the following spools.
Polymakr Black Spool 55.2ｍｍ 　( 54.4mm )
eSUN Black Spool 53.5ｍｍ 　( 52.8mm )
eSUN Clear Spool 51.60mm 　 ( 51.0mm )
pratique pour Anet A8

title: Z-Brace for Monoprice Maker Select Plus

description.text:
I've collected all of the parts from both the parent project and the grandparent project.

The parent project didn't include the top braces nor the ball nuts, and two of the STLs were mangled (front right was miniaturized, back right didn't render properly).

These problems should be resolved now. Included in the pics is the actual hardware I used:

Qty 1: metal glides (feet), 1-1/16 inch 4pk
Qty 8: Socket Cap Screws M3 x 0.5 x 12mm (they come in packs of 3, so I needed to buy 3 packs)
Qty 4: Socket Cap Screws M5 x 0.8 x 12mm (they come in packs of 2, so I needed to buy 2 packs)

Qty 1: 36 inch 5/16-18 Threaded Rod (You'll need to cut this in half.
Qty 4: 5/16-18 Nylock Nuts
Qty 2: 5/16-18 Regular Hex Nut

For further details and advice, check the parent project and the grandparent project.

Important Note: While I show all of the parts on a single print bed, I'd advise against printing them all at once- if one piece chokes halfway through, it'll waste all of the filament.

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

title: My take on a Pythagoras cup

description.text: This is a personal take on a Pythagoras Cup. Pythagoras cups are also called "Greedy Cups." these cups have a main reservoir like most other glasses, but it also has a "secret" channel running along the inside that leads from inside the reservoir out the bottom of the cup. the story behind these varies but the just of it is that you give this cup "secretly" to someone who might try to fill it all the way to the top and if they do the channel fills up then starts a siphon and takes all the liquid out of the glass.

description.text:
Update - 01/08/17: I made one....110 hours printing time, 1 full roll of filament. I printed the scope at 90% (saved a bit of filament - 30 meters to be exact -, and doesn't look quite so bulky).

Update - 19/7/17 ; Just tidied up all the original stl files, pushed them through netfabb and re-uploaded them.

The Omolon TestRR1 Sniper Rifle.
The destinystlgenerator was generous this time...all the little tiny pieces, it gave me three of everything! Pfffft.
This measures 1034mm long. Please read the printing instructions.
The scope is not exactly as pictured. The one on the rifle is the one that came from destinystlgenerator.

Notes:

There are 5 pieces that are between 230 and 260 long. Obbviously these will not fit on a standard 200 x 200 bed. But they WILL fit if you turn the pieces 45deg...on the diagonal.
Supports are recommende for several pieces...you'll be able to tell which ones.
The sections are joined together with joiners to line everything up. They are numbered with...well....numbers actually. :)

Don't own a 3d printer?

I know some of you probably don't own a 3d printer, yet (I didn't when I first joined thingiverse). If you would like to have this printed for you, you can order it from my website: http://scalemodelprints.com/store/?c=40
During checkout, use the coupon code IMATHINGIFAN to get 25% off. Prices are in New Zealand dollars.

description.text: Did this remix of Alex's great wheel scad to support Hex shafts.  Alex has the changes and will merge this into the baseline soon.

I spended 15+ hrs on this model, so if you have some spare money, i would not mind a tip :)
If you played Stalker-Call of Pripyat, you must used one of theese bad boys. I modeled it in solidworks2010 according to some old pdf drawings and screenshot from game which i found on internet. Im personally big fan of Stalker, so i really payed attention on some details. There are 3 stl files, but dont expect that you will just print and play with it, there is probably little bit of sanding, fitting, painting. I didnt maked buttons, but you can if you want. In future i will probably model bezel (screen, call it what you want) and include some arduino inside of housing with even maybe some geiger counter. Im also including my original solidworks files, so if you have enough skills and time, feel free to edit 'em and fit your electronic inside of it. I would like if i had little bit more time on this project, but maybe in future ill get back on it. For now, this is it, if you have any question, feel free to ask and....

...GOOD HUNTING, STALKER! :)

Here is a fidget spinner I designed in Fusion 360. I will post pictures and print settings when I print this. I'm not sure if the caps work or not (again, I'll post an update after I print them).

UPDATE: I have successfully printed both the spinner and the caps. The print settings I used are available below.

Like most fidget spinners, this spinner uses 608zz (22m) skateboard bearings.
Best prints can be achieved by orienting it flat on the bed and using supports. Higher infill will lead to longer spin times.

Finder

After removing supports, I had some trouble fitting the 608 bearing in the hole. You can either scale everything 1% larger, or heat the print with a hairdryer to make the hole bigger.

The caps should fit snugly in the holes of the bearing.

description.text:
I was tired of knocking my USB HDD off the table whenever I slid my computer around or when one of the cats decided to jump around on my laptop. This was specifically drawn up for a Seagate SRD00F1 and a Dell 14Z but should work with other combos, especially if you scale it around.

It was kinda flimsy while printing so I uploaded a beefier version as well.

I printed this upside down with no supports and a very, very slow top layer. Designed to work best with a 0.4mm nozzle (walls are all 1.6 or 1.2mm) at 100% scale.

Printer:

MPSM

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2625

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you've got good cooling and go slow, you won't need any supports.

This is another single mosfet bracket. It replaces the two bottom spacers of the mainboard and hangs the mosfet below.

The main redesign here is to reverse the screw and nut from other designs. The screw head is countersunk from the bottom allowing a wider range of screw lengths (3mm x 18mm are what I used).

comments.text: Thanks for this! I've just printed and installed it and it works great! Uses a lot less plastic than the other mounts I've seen and avoids the need for drilling holes.
comments.author: grantjames

description.text: Made from measurements of a simple wooden boat from the home workshop of physicist Aaron Lemonick https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Lemonick

Holds everything in place while you transport your Robo3D printer.
I added a handle! Remove before Use ;)

Printed using 0.2mm layer height, flat against the surface to minimize Z height.  It's best to install the bed clip on the bed & top of rail first, then slide it into the bottom rail.  
Also best to print out of ABS -- having this melt in your car would be most un-fun.  
Depending on the roughness of handling, you might also want to make flexible coupling savers (this holds z axis down on the nuts).  
To make the handle, print 2x Base + 2x Connector +1x handle.  The dovetails in the connector & handle are tight and not meant to come apart, but the connectors should slide easily on/off the bases (there's a recess inside so they shouldn't come out by accident).  The bases snap though the slot in the top of the Robo3d, and they have points on them for locator holes so they won't slide in the slot.  You should be able to leave the bases in place during printing.  
Remove before Use ;)

title: 1 Relay Board Enclosure (for "Low Level Trigger" relay)

description.text:
This enclosure is for 1 relay board 5v (low trigger), it sells on aliexpress for US$0.60.
Link: https://goo.gl/przNA9

To hold the board, you must use hot glue to stick the relay to bottom enclosure, and to close the enclosure permanent you must glue the lid to enclosure.

it took almost 40 mins to print. at 0.15mm resolution.

NOTE: Just a note, not relevant for the enclosure.
This relay does not work good on Raspberry Pi, because it is a low level trigger, I use a workaround to make it work; set GPIOs to IN or OUT instead of HIGH or LOW to make the relay switch.
Im also test this relay with esp8266 esp-01 module standalone and with this it work perfect.
here is the link for the ESP8266 esp01 module: https://goo.gl/RyD1Ox.

remixed_from.author: aaroncm
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 E3D v6 HotEnd Mount With Sensor (12mm and 18mm)

description.text:
I liked aaroncm's minimal/simple hotend mount, I had been using it for a while.
But I want to use two hotends on it, so I measured the original model and got it close to the original in OpenSCAD.

Everything is square in my scad because I don't know how to make rounded shapes that won't deform their original size in OpenSCAD.

I designed this so the values are all in variables that someone can change.
There is also a setting to specify how many hotends you want. I only needed two, but it works past 10... I have no limit on it.

If there is any suggestions, or ways I can improve my program, please let me know. I'm a fluent programmer, but I'm a novice with OpenSCAD still.

I did not design this with a proximity sensor mount because I am using a modified rear mount that attaches to the back of the i3 remix carriage.

comments.text:
What plate does this mount to? I have a plate designed for the p802m and wanted to see if that could be adapted for this. I have the second e3d hotend right here and waiting. I used this setup for my new hotend - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1352588
THanks!!!
comments.author: plaguereign

comments.text:
Should work with any Prusa i3 Rework compatible carriages/plates.
The 4 mounting holes are a little closer in then the normal i3 carriages/plates I believe.
The distance between the center of the mounting holes should be 23mm. Just measure yours and see how close it is, or you might have to print out a new carriage/plate. Or you could always modify my OpenSCAD file to the dimensions you need.

remixed_from.author: punkkills
remixed_from.title: Micro 105 FPV Quadcopter - 8.5mm Motors, Micro Scisky

title: Hubsan x4 105mm FPV Quadcopter (Based off punkkills' Micro 105 FPV)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an FPV conversion frame for the Hubsan X4 107c.

  • You will have to remove the camera that comes with the Hubsan X4,
  • You must shorten, remove, or tape down the four corner lights (I shortened one of the red lights and removed the rest, there's blue leds on the board for syncing)
  • The original screws used to mount the board in the Hubsan X4 will fit the mount/stand offs, I do not know the size, I know that all of the screws that hold together the Hubsan X4 107c will fit these holes.
  • To complete this frame you must download one of the tops from punkkills' Micro 105 FPV Quadcopter. I have named my frames v3 and v4 as they are equivalent with punkkills' v3 and v4 frames.

For info on FPV gear read the sections in punkkills' post titled: "All in One FPV Gear", "DIY FPV Gear", and "Video Options"

As per the suggestion of punkkills, you may use nylon nuts and machine screws.
Personally I have only used the printable Screw Replacements by navyblueboss.

Settings suggested by punkkills

Infill: 100%
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Bottom Piece: 4 Perimeters
Top Piece: 2 Perimeters
Extrusion Width: 0.48mm

This frame is heavily based off of punkkills' Micro 105 FPV Quadcopter, specifically his V3 and V4 frames which improved on the strength of his earlier versions and added a battery mount respectively. This has the same dimensions as punkkills' frame as far as the motor placement and screw holes for the top. All of the credit for this design goes to punkkills.

I will be adding pictures of the frame and cleaning up the summary in the coming days.

Maybe it will come in handy for someone else. Make sure you measure twice so you only have to print once.

author: MikeGolfJ3

description.text: This is a model of BB-8 from Star Wars: The Force Awakens. I designed this model over the course of 3 days and about 20 hours in Autodesk Inventor. Included is a file for just the body, a file for just the head, and a file of everything as one piece for smaller prints. The head and body have no designated joint, meaning the head can be positioned anywhere on the body with glue or other means.

title: MP3 player and headphone mount for my desk door
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a secure place to keep my MP3 player while charging it.
The player holder has a cord retainer on one end.
The headphone holder just keeps the phones secure from falling. As designed the holders are about 15mm wide where they mount on the door.

Printed these in glow in the dark PLA. Support is required, and should be used.
I set my support in slicer to be 70%, making it easy to break out.

author: suzysheer66

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Filament Guide for Wanhao i3 plus

description.text:
A teflon tube assisted filament guide for your Wanhao Duplicator I3 Plus! Also fits the I3 (non-plus.)

A mirrored version (file labeled bottom) fits the non-plus better as well as gets the guide closer to the extruder. Thanks to mnccouk for this idea!

You can use longer than a 5mm teflon tube, this is just the minimum to fit inside.

UPDATE: New "18mm" files should line up better.
Picture added: I align my cooling block all the way back on the carriage. Mounting holes are oblong.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

~20%

5mm of Teflon tubing required.

Cut Teflon with razor blade to prevent making out-of-round.
Slightly persuade tube into appropriate hole with blunt object.
Use existing screws!
You're done!

author: SweetSweetCookies

title: Spyda / Crossfire Quadcopter Arm with removable / replaceable foot

description.text:
I was thinking about solving the problem with feet of my quadcopter arms breaking off after hard landings. I created the more stable foot (here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:229300) but printing this thing with 50% infill takes 4.5h.
So I created this arm with replaceable foot. If the foot breaks, just pull the remaining piece with some pliers and plug it the spare part and you are done! Much less printing time, be faster up in the air again, save filament and money. The foot will fit the hole very tight, so it will not fall of during flight. Depeding on your printer setup it will be a VERY tight fit.

description.text:
This is a pretty straightforward fidget spinner with two distinctions. It takes 5/8" loose ball bearings on the arms, which fit precisely so they also rotate freely. Uses a standard skate bearing (608) in the center like others. Both the spinner caps and arms can be embossed with a 100x100 PNG image. You will need to print 2 caps. Otherwise pretty basic spinner. OpenSCAD files provided.

The bearing in the center should fit pretty tightly. The loose bearings on the arms should snap in from the top side and then rotate freely. If the dimensions don't come out perfectly on your printer, the OpenSCAD files have "tweak" variables you can use to get a secure fit.

title: Camping Stove Hose Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Clips to keep my camping stove's hose more organised.

Suits my hose's diameter of 11.5mm. Design file available at Onshape.

I found it best to print at least two of these clips and space them wide apart (at least 80mm) on the print bed to prevent the radiant heat from the extruder deforming the print. Also, slow the print speed down to ensure the object doesn't delaminate from the bed.

Printed with 0.2mm layer height. I prefer to use PETG because of its strength and flexibility. Only 1 perimeter is needed and a low infill was used to allow for some flex.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

title: Genesis Coupe 2013+ bumper spacer for easy intake mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
While working on the car I decided to do this project, the "Easy intake mod":
http://www.gencoupe.com/3-8-v6-discussion-2013-up/440546-easy-stock-intake-mod.html
It involves removing a plastic baffle that improves airflow to the intake of the car (works, BTW).
When you finally figure out how to get it detached from the bumper (there are clips that hold it on. start at one side and work your way in) you are left with some plastic trim bolts that only loosely fit (see the second photo on that thread).
This spacer is the thickness of the removed component and fits fully under the clip and covers the rectangular part of the opening. The protrusion holds it firmly by pressing against the bottom part of the opening to prevent rotation and vibration of the spacer.

title: Bowden Tube Mount and Retainer Ring

description.text: This is a clamp and mount for PTFE Bowden tube to be used as a guide to the extruder. I'm using Ikea Lack tables as an enclosure, and have been using this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2228363 to guide the filament through the upper table. Problem is, the filament eventually wears a groove in the bottom of the guide if you do not have a straight down shot to your extruder. This would cause the filament to drag and jerk and make a horrible noise. Using this clamp and retainer ring, you can use some standard Bowden tube to guide the filament from the spool through the table to the extruder. This completely eliminated the noise and made the filament feed much, much smoother. You will need to use supports both outside and inside the tube to print properly. Use about 20%.

Printer:

FLSUN I3 Clone Modified

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Support Removal.

Be careful removing the supports from inside the tube holder. It's best to gently break the tabs of the tube holder away from the support, then take a razor and continue the separation down to the base. Then take a very small flat screwdriver from the back to break the support inside loose. Last, either use the screwdriver to pull the support out from the back, or a pair of small pliers. Sometimes the back of the support will come out on it's own. If that happens, use the small screwdriver to push the remaining support out the front. The retaining ring is very tight. Put the ring over the tube, then just barely insert the tube in the clamp. Once the tube is slightly in, take a pair of pliers with one hand, and the tube with the other, and push the ring (outside) and hose (inside) both into the clamp at the same time until they bottom out.

title: Whiteboard Connector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Instead of mounting multiple whiteboards side by side and having a large unusable gap between from the aluminium frame, you can carefully remove one side of the frame from each whiteboard (or two, if it's not on the end of the row) and use these parts to attach them together, resulting in a much smaller unusable gap. The connector takes the place of the plastic corner pieces where two boards meet, and the plates can be used to add a bit of extra strength/stability to the joint (as many as you like, though the boards we used had four screws holding the side of the frame on, so we reused those screws for four plates per joint) - just lay a plate across the joint and screw through the holes into each board.

The whiteboards we used were Penrite branded, though others may also work if they use sufficiently similar aluminium edging. You may also find that the frame is glued as well as screwed on to the board, in which case the frame may end up getting bent during the removal process (and you may end up with small chunks of the fibre board being torn out), though older versions of the same whiteboard seem to use a much denser backing board and no glue.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

100% infill used as these are load-bearing parts. Supports touching print bed only, to support the "wings" on the connector.

Designed using OpenSCAD, using the original corner piece as a reference. The initial revision tried to stay too close to the design of the original corner piece, resulting in insufficient strength (especially when coupled with a poor quality print), so I redesigned it to increase the strength without extending beyond the whiteboard surface (and cleaned/calibrated my printer). I haven't yet designed a cap/cover (equivalent to that found on the original corner pieces), but there are mounting holes for one.

description.text:
Tanque oruga, para incluir una placa arduino encima. Las ruedas van pegadas con pegamento para que quede una ranura por donde entra la oruga de goma. LLeva dos servos miniatura de rotación continua. El guardabarros trasero no es simétrico y hay que pegarlo con pegamento por detrás de donde va la batería. La placa arduino hay que fijarla con cinta adhesiva a dos caras, Para tensar las orugas he puesto el eje delantero movible, que se sujeta con unos tornillos por debajo de M3. Las ruedas giran libremente en unos tornillos largos de métrica 2,5 más o menos, a lo mejor hay que repasar un poco con una lima el agujero de las ruedas con el fin de evitar holguras y que el tornillo entre justito y gire libremente. Para que no se salgan las orugas, conviene centrar bien el eje delantero. Las ruedas que van atrás van pegadas con pegamento a los soportes que traen todos los servos.
Las orugas las he comprado aquí:
http://es.opitec.com/opitec-web/articleNumber/804925/zz/cID/c3I6b3J1Z2
y los servos de rotación continua aquí:
http://www.electan.com/feetech-fs90r-micro-continuous-rotation-servo-p-6173.html
un video de funcionamiento
https://youtu.be/y36uUW7gMyY

P3STEEL

  • 6 x 6mm diameter x (16mm to 20mm) long bolts, matching nuts, and 6 washers (one per bolt)

this is my work of the last days.
i whant to add some more details and additional parts..
a tyer stand, some flags, trees and so on... all is click fit, just push it together no need any glue.
with pla, all fits together perfect and hold strong and dont fall into parts, with abs some sanding was needed, but maybe its my abs settings. upper parts are made in abs (white parts) the rest is printed in pla with 0.2 layer high and 60mm/s. only some parts need a little bit of support, you can turn support on,
it will only use a little bit.

with only 20% infill was not fully closed and dont looks as good as the one with 25% infill. on my photos it is my prototype print, i think it can be printed mutch nicer. i have added my sketchup file, so if you like to change or add anything... for matchbox cars size, skale down 20% or so. TODO:

remixed_from.title: Customizable spinner caps for any bearing

description.text:
I liked the original’s idea of the cuts to get a bit of holding force, and that you had a customizer.
Unfortunately, when i typed in that i wanted a “685” bearing, i didn’t get an error message, but the default, a 608 bearing.
Turns out, there were no 11 mm ⌀ bearings in the list.

So i added an entry for the 5 mm × 11 mm × 5 mm bearing as “685”.
I also fixed it so you really get 10 bearings when you set that, not 12.
(But it looks like it’s not working for quantity 1. Oops.)

The coin (⌀ 16.25 mm) and SD card adaptor (24 mm × 32 mm) are there for scale.

description.text:
I made a little RPi Zero W case for my octopi setup since I couldn't find anything specific for it. It made to be mountable using a couple of M4 wood screws.

The whole design uses no extra hardware and everything should be able to press fit together (depending on your printers tolerances). You will want to insert the RPi camera header first to prevent the little black tab from breaking.....trust me, I learnt the hard way.

The STEP and F3D files are also available in case you want to remix it or customize the design in any way you please.

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.24mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports aren't necessary but will give the I/O ports a nicer finish since they are a little filleted on the corners and thus can cause a little bit of stringing.

comments.text: You could easily avoid that " little bit of stringing" by moving the part line (between the lid and the box) down into the plane of the openings and printing the lid upside down with half of the opening in the lid and half in the box.

author: krassi1919

title: To the end of the school count

description.text: To the end of the school count

include

include "RTClib.h"

RTC_DS3231 rtc;

include "sevenSegmentDisplay.h"

int A = 7 ;
int B = 8 ;
int C = 9 ;
int D = 10 ;
int E = 11 ;
int F = 12 ;
int G = 13 ;
int a = 0 ;
int b = 1 ;
int c = 2 ;
int d = 3 ;
int e = 4 ;
int f = 5 ;
int g = 6 ;
sevenSegmentDisplay sevseg1(COMMON_ANODE, a, b, c, d, e, f, g, -1);
sevenSegmentDisplay sevseg2(COMMON_CATHODE, A, B, C, D, E, F, G, -1);

int licznik=0;
int cyfr_1=0;
int cyfr_2=0;

long JulianDate(int year, int month, int day)
{
long centuries = year/100;
long leaps = centuries/4;
long leapDays = 2 - centuries + leaps; // note is negative!!
long yearDays = 365.25 (year + 4716); // days until 1 jan this year
long monthDays = 30.6001 (month + 1); // days until 1st month
long jd = leapDays + day + monthDays + yearDays -1524.5;
return jd;
}

void setup() {
// put your setup code here, to run once:
sevseg1.off();
sevseg2.off();
delay(1000); // wait for console opening

if (! rtc.begin()) { //Jesli jest problem z zegarkiem, to wyswietli sie Er na wyswietlaczu
sevseg1.set('E');
sevseg2.set('r');
while (1);
}

if (rtc.lostPower()) {
// following line sets the RTC to the date & time this sketch was compiled
rtc.adjust(DateTime(F(DATE), F(TIME)));
// This line sets the RTC with an explicit date & time, for example to set
// January 21, 2014 at 3am you would call:
// rtc.adjust(DateTime(2014, 1, 21, 3, 0, 0));
}

}

long dzien_docelowy = JulianDate(2017,06,12);

void loop() {
DateTime now = rtc.now();
long dzien_obecny = JulianDate(now.year(),now.month(),now.day());
long dni_do_celu= dzien_docelowy-dzien_obecny;

//Rozbijamy licznik na dwie cyfry
if (dni_do_celu>99) { //Wyswietl 99 jesli dni do celu jest wiecej niz 99
cyfr_1=9;
cyfr_2=9;
}
else {
cyfr_1=(dni_do_celu/10)%10;
cyfr_2=dni_do_celu%10;
}
//Wyswietlamy!
sevseg1.set(cyfr_1); //Wyswietlenie cyfry pierwszej na pierwszym wyswietlaczu
sevseg2.set(cyfr_2); //Wyswietlenie cyfry drugiej na drugim wyswietlaczu

delay(30000); //opoznienie 30 sekund, mozna duzo wiecej:)
}

include "sevenSegmentDisplay.h"

sevenSegmentDisplay::sevenSegmentDisplay(bool _displayType, uint8_t A, uint8_t B, uint8_t C, uint8_t D, uint8_t E, uint8_t F, uint8_t G, uint8_t DP)
{
displayType = _displayType;

segmentPin[0] = A;
segmentPin[1] = B;
segmentPin[2] = C;
segmentPin[3] = D;
segmentPin[4] = E;
segmentPin[5] = F;
segmentPin[6] = G;
segmentPin[7] = DP;

for(uint8_t segment = 0; segment < 7; segment++) pinMode(segmentPin[segment], OUTPUT);
this->off();

}

void sevenSegmentDisplay::off()
{
for(uint8_t segment = 0; segment < 7; segment++)
if( displayType == COMMON_CATHODE ) digitalWrite(segmentPin[segment], LOW);
else digitalWrite(segmentPin[segment], HIGH);
}

void sevenSegmentDisplay::set(uint8_t symbol)
{
// scroll down for the explanation of the switch case

if( symbol > 9 )
    switch( symbol )
    {
        case 'A':
            symbol = 10;
            break;

        case 'b':
            symbol = 11;
            break;

        case 'C':
            symbol = 12;
            break;

        case 'c':
            symbol = 13;
            break;

        case 'd':
            symbol = 14;
            break;

        case 'E':
            symbol = 15;
            break;

        case 'F':
            symbol = 16;
            break;

        case 'H':
            symbol = 17;
            break;

        case 'h':
            symbol = 18;
            break;

        case 'I':
            symbol = 19;
            break;

        case 'J':
            symbol = 20;
            break;

        case 'L':
            symbol = 21;
            break;

        case 'n':
            symbol = 22;
            break;

        case 'o':
            symbol = 23;
            break;

        case 'P':
            symbol = 24;
            break;

        case 'q':
            symbol = 25;
            break;

        case 'r':
            symbol = 26;
            break;

        case 't':
            symbol = 27;
            break;

        case 'U':
            symbol = 28;
            break;

        case 'u':
            symbol = 29;
            break;

        case 'y':
            symbol = 30;
            break;

        default:
            if(symbol > 30)
            {
                this->off();
                return;
            }
    }

/* Because in the symbolMap array, arrays for some alphabetic symbols are missing,
   the allowed alphabetic symbols are discontinuous and consequently the same is for their ASCII values.
   This means that the characters that match the relative symbols need to be "manually" remapped 
   to the correct index number to allow them to match the correct array in the symbolMap array.

   If it is unclear have a look to the header file.
*/

for(uint8_t segment = 0; segment < 7; segment++)
    if( displayType == COMMON_CATHODE ) digitalWrite(segmentPin[segment], symbolMap[symbol][segment]);
    else digitalWrite(segmentPin[segment], !symbolMap[symbol][segment]);

}

void sevenSegmentDisplay::setSegment(uint8_t segment, bool value)
{
if( segment == DP ) segment = 7; //the decimal point is the 7th segment, note that a constant named 'DP' is defined in the header
else
{
if( ( segment < 'A' ) || ( ( segment > 'G' ) && ( segment < 'a' ) ) || ( segment > 'g' ) ) return; //if a non-allowed value is assigned to segment, do nothing
else if( segment >= 'a' ) segment -= 97;
else if( segment >= 'A' ) segment -= 65;

/* The variable "segment" can be a char from 'A' to 'G' and from 'a' to 'g'

   Because 'A' represent the first segment ( segment 0 ) and his ASCII value is 65,
   65 is subtracted in order to make 'A' = 0 and the successive chars in match with the symbolMap index.

   Likewise 'a' represent the first segment ( segment 0 ) and his ASCII value is 97, then
   97 is subtracted in order to make 'a' = 0 and the successive chars in match with the symbolMap index.
*/

} 

if( displayType == COMMON_CATHODE ) digitalWrite(segmentPin[segment], value);
else digitalWrite(segmentPin[segment], !value);

}

ifndef sevenSegmentDisplay_lib_by_HackerInside

define sevenSegmentDisplay_lib_by_HackerInside

include

ifndef common_constants_for_xSegmentDisplay_lib_by_HackerInside //This makes it possible to use more of my libraries to display segments in the same code

define common_constants_for_xSegmentDisplay_lib_by_HackerInside

define COMMON_CATHODE 0 //this is one of the values that the variable displayType can assume

define COMMON_ANODE 1 //this is one of the values that the variable displayType can assume

const uint8_t DP = 255; //this is used to identify the decimal point segment in the setSegment method

endif // common_constants_for_xSegmentDisplay_lib_by_HackerInside

class sevenSegmentDisplay
{
public:

    sevenSegmentDisplay(bool displayType, uint8_t A, uint8_t B, uint8_t C, uint8_t D, uint8_t E, uint8_t F, uint8_t G, uint8_t DP);

    void off();
    void set(uint8_t symbol);
    void setSegment(uint8_t segment, bool value);

protected:

    uint8_t segmentPin[8];
    bool displayType;

private:

    //uint8_t segmentPin[8];
    const bool symbolMap[31][7] //this array maps the state of each segment for each simbol
    {
    //  {a,b,c,d,e,f,g},
        {1,1,1,1,1,1,0}, // zero
        {0,1,1,0,0,0,0}, // one
        {1,1,0,1,1,0,1}, // two
        {1,1,1,1,0,0,1}, // three
        {0,1,1,0,0,1,1}, // four
        {1,0,1,1,0,1,1}, // five
        {1,0,1,1,1,1,1}, // six
        {1,1,1,0,0,0,0}, // seven
        {1,1,1,1,1,1,1}, // eight
        {1,1,1,1,0,1,1}, // nine

        {1,1,1,0,1,1,1}, // A
        {0,0,1,1,1,1,1}, // b
        {1,0,0,1,1,1,0}, // C
        {0,0,0,1,1,0,1}, // c
        {0,1,1,1,1,0,1}, // d
        {1,0,0,1,1,1,1}, // E
        {1,0,0,0,1,1,1}, // F
        //G not allowed
        {0,1,1,0,1,1,1}, // H
        {0,0,1,0,1,1,1}, // h
        {0,0,0,0,1,1,0}, // I
        {0,1,1,1,0,0,0}, // J
        //K not allowed
        {0,0,0,1,1,1,0}, // L
        //M not allowed
        {0,0,1,0,1,0,1}, // n
        {0,0,1,1,1,0,1}, // o
        {1,1,0,0,1,1,1}, // P
        {1,1,1,0,0,1,1}, // q
        {0,0,0,0,1,0,1}, // r
        //S is equal to five
        {0,0,0,1,1,1,1}, // t
        {0,1,1,1,1,1,0}, // U
        {0,0,1,1,1,0,0}, // u
        //V not allowed
        //W not allowed
        //X not allowed
        {0,1,1,1,0,1,1}, // y
        //Z not allowed
    };

};

endif // sevenSegmentDisplay_lib_by_HackerInside

title: Indestructible 3D printed Hexagonal Lattice shape with Anet A8

description.text:
Here is my test video. In this video I showed you Indestructible 3D printed objects with Anet A8 and go over it with my car.

Don't forget to check the picture for print parameters!!!

Note: The usage of tough ink requires a 3D printer that pull the filament NOT PUSHes. So that your extruder motor should be on the extruder head. Else you wont be able to print the tough ink. And If you want you can use the flow rate as 110% to extrude well if you have experience problems.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gUsog8NRgD8
If you like it don't forget to subscribe to my channel!

Feel free to download hexagonal lattice structure's stl file

If you are wondering about anet A8 and wish to purchase is here are the link for you to check it out

title: Clip for glass plate of 4mm for Anet A6 A8

description.text:
I couldn't find a proper clip for my mirror bed of 4mm. I made these with tinkercad to hold my bed now. It works perfectly in my case. i made the gap 6.9mm for all models for an extra tight grip. I use 8 v2's to hold my bed. Can be printed standing up for best results, but lying down works also. Here are all 3 versions i designed:

  • side_clip_6_9_mm.stl : Biggest clip I started with, sturdy but cumbersome.
  • Smaller_clip_7mm_1.stl : Smaller clip with edged sides, still to big for probe, but sturdy
  • Smaller_clip_7mm_v2.stl : Smallest clip only 1mm high, probe will hover over it! but not the sturdiest. Hope it will last.

title: Side Table for IKEA Solvinden
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have create a side table to mount on an IKEA Solvinden solar powered floor LED lamp. Two versions are uploaded, one (dual1 and dual2) are targeted at dual extrusion machines, and the mono version is for a single extrusion machine.

The table can be mounted on the lamp by unscrewing the top rod. It rests on the knob between the two rods. The top plate is a little bit skewed and has water drain holes in the center.

I have only printed the dual version, so did not test the STL of the mono version. Any feedback is welcome.

Note: use the table at own risk, do not overload and be aware that PLA will degrade over time especially in outside conditions.

Marco

title: Fabrikator mini v2 spool holder – optimized

description.text:
I tried Glennbeekhof's spool holder, but it did not fit on my Fabrikator, so I redesigned it.

  • bigger slot to fit on the machine without force
  • connection bar in the middle of the slot
  • the rod is now a little deeper (3 mm) in relation to the connection part
  • the rod is shorter (65 mm, better center of gravity)
  • visually appealing, smaller cover plate

It fits perfect for my Das Filament 800 g spools (outer diameter 200 mm, inner diameter 52 mm, spool width 55 mm).

Made with FreeCAD.

author: bmslee

description.text:
Finished print of an amiibo design.

I can't provide much detail of print process because I had it done for me!
All i can say for certain is that it's sandstone

Printer:

ProJet CJP 660Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

The belt grips that are used on the SmartAlu to attach the four GT2 belt ends to the X-carriage appeared to be a little bit loose on mine, which resulted on loosing a tooth or two sometimes, and ultimately having one end of the belt actually detached. You can imagine the effect on the printing… ;)

So I remade them, making sure they would be tight enough, and with a few more teeth than the original, to hold the belt ends safely, but not too much of course, to make sure it would still be easy to insert the belt.

This is quite easy and fast to print and replace. I'd suggest you print it slowly and with a good resolution (at least 0.2mm layer height) to make sure the shape of the pieces is accurate, and therefore efficient. :)

print_settings.Notes:: I printed on a Prusa i3 mk2 turning the print 45degrees so it sat diagonally across the board allowed it to fit.

A sword made in the old classic way, only with wood and laser. No for sparring purpose - this sword will break and is oversize anyway.

Instructions:
1) Use laser to cut the DXF files .Use 4 mm wood.
2) assemble the parts and glue them together. the two largest peaces are in the middle and the smallest parts on the top and bottom layer.
3) 3D print the STL files.
4) insert the guard to the small squire "tail" of the wood peace.
Optional: Secure the guard with glue.
5) Hammer down the handle into the "tail". Caution : parts may break if they made from soft materiel.
6) Hammer down softly the pommel.
7) Display the sword to your friends.

author: mussy

title: Ferrite bead anti pull out cone

description.text:
A cone to put on a cable, close to a ferrite bead. This is to keep the bead from catching on a table edge and pulling out the cable with it. I use it on a scanner that sits on the back edge of my desk most of the time. When i want to use it, i pull it to the front edge. Without this thing, i constantly pulled out the cable and hand to dive under the desk to retrieve it.

The connecting mechanism doesn’t really work, and i had to fix the two halves with sticky tape. The cone does it job, so i won’t work out a perfect vitamin free solution.

After printing the old Version from other Members, i had the Problem with the Bedleveling and the Nozzel after "Home All" (see at the first 4 Pics). This is my Improvment to fix the Problem. Um des Bedleveling Problem zu lösen habe ich dem Kabel mehr Platz verschaft. Um das Düsen Problem zu beheben habe ich den Kabelkettengliederanschluss weiter nach unten verlegt (siehe Bilder 5 und 6)
Version2 und Version2a ist für den nachträglichen Einbau.
Version2b ist für die komplette Neumontage.

title: 3D Printable RC Spitfire (Original)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS

I have been very busy with my final year at university so I have not had the chance to improve this as it is still very heavy and the weight needs to be reduced.

I have also noticed that there are several people who have taken this design from MyMiniFactory and have uploaded the design on different websites claiming it as there design. I really do not mind people sharing and improving my work but please give credit as it takes a lot of effort to design something like this from scratch and it sucks to see people using my work and claiming that they made the design.

I will probably create another RC Plane design from scratch in the summer holidays when I purchase some new electronics.

This is a functional RC Airplane that is based on the Supermarine Spitfire Mk VIII. This is a 4 Channel RC Airplane.

Instructions:

  • Print all Parts with 2 Shells and 10% Infill (The part was designed to be printed with 2 shells however if possible you can also try to print with 1 shell to reduce weight)
  • All the parts have already been orientated correctly so that they print without any problems.
  • Most of the parts are support free, but there are few parts that will require a little bit of support that will need to be removed after the model is printed.
  • The parts will need to be joined together using a strong plastic glue. I have used the folloing (
  • It is possible to use Carbon Fibre Rods in the wings to increase strength, although that removes the dihedral wing effect.

Note: When Building the plane I highly recommend that you attach the motor first to the nose before gluing the nose to the middle section or else it will be very hard to attach the motor later on.

Parts Required:

I am still in the process of testing different Electronics with this RC Model for the best result, so I will not be giving any specific list of electronics.

Required:

  • 1x Brushless Motor
  • 1x ESC
  • 4x 9g Servos or 5g Servos – Have not tested the 5g servos but they will fit much better whereas with some 9g servos you need to remove the plastic screw holders so that they fit.
  • 4x Servo Horns
  • 4x Servo Push Rods – I am just using 0.8mm Piano Wire
  • Battery – If you’re using a big battery you will need to manually cut the centre plastic from the middle section so that it fits.
  • Minimum 4CH Transmitter and Receiver
  • CA Glue and CA Hinges.

Optional:

  • Flite Controller – For Auto levelling and Stabilisation
  • Carbon Fibre Rods
  • FPV Camera and Transmitter – The hole in the top canopy is to for FPV cameras
  • FPV Receiver and Monitor

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Resolution:

0.1

comments.text:
Hi. I am making a 3D labs P47 but would also like to try this as it looks more detailed than most.
I think, having done one thin wall print, I would like a single wall with infill. Is there a single wall version of the.stl files, or how do I make one as still learning the object editor. I am sure blender could do it but I am struggling with it.
Having tried it I think Cura's 'lines' infill might work as they produce an X support from end to end of a wing (for example) and I think it may just work with little weight increase, like swapping the inner shell for the infill. I will also try increasing size by 150% to give about 1m span, this should try to hit a print weight of 500g to fly based on other models.

author: stijnpeeters

title: Drela AG13 Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (29.92g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
I designed this drone propeller with the Drela AG13 airfoil coordinates. All testing was done on the Micro Drone Propeller Thrust Tester (test results below).

It was printed slowly, with a 0.2 nozzle at 0.04 layer height. I deburred and cleaned the print using a Precision Knife

After this, I went on and sanded it with a piece of 500 grit sandpaper.

These are the readings for a few voltage presets (you can also view these in the images taken during the test):

  • 1.5V => 9.66 grams
  • 2V => 10.96 grams
  • 2.5V => 26.17 grams
  • 3V => 29.92 grams

The files that are included contain all pictures relevant to the test, along with 6 txt files that contain airfoil coordinates, the printable STL files and finally the SLDPRT files. If you want to play with the propeller, make sure you have a 8520 coreless motor.

You can use the SLDPRT extension files, in case you want to make your own changes to the drone propeller.

Note: Airfoil plotted with the matplotlib library in python.
