Notes:

I suggest printing stand-up.

The Menger sponge is a fractal object that has any number of interesting mathematical properties and one unexpected and very attractive physical property, which George Hart explored in a video and a page on his website. There have been a number of Menger sponges on Thingiverse, including one set up to show the diagonal cut that Prof. Hart discusses. I could never get that part to slice correctly, so I made my own in OpenSCAD. That said, my second-order version gave Slic3r some problems as well, so I've also included the STL after being fixed by Netfabb Cloud. For either first or second-order, you'll need two copies to make a full cube.

The half-cubes should slice and print very easily. As noted in the description, Slic3r has some issues with the second-order file; once I processed it through Netfabb Cloud it was fine, so that STL is included as well.   
One other Slic3r tip - for some reason a concentric first layer produces a nice solid first layer for the first-order cube, but gaps for the second-order. I found that rectilinear fill for the first layer worked better.  
The first-order examples were printed on an OB1.4 using Printrbot PLA and the second-order were printed on a Printrbot Jr with SainSmart PLA, both at 0.3 mm layers, 20% infill, 3 perimeters and top/bottom. The Printrbot Jr lacks a heated bed, so the bottom of the print curled a little bit; it's not noticeable by itself, but keeps the two halves from fitting together well.

It fits perfect to the original screws of the Wanhao i3 plus.
Update 15.06.2017: Added two M6 knobs for even better handling.

comments.text: A couple of suggestions:
comments.author: siefertma

comments.text: Yep, no problem. I'll try and get onto that in the next couple of days.
comments.author: siefertma

comments.text: I attempted to print this model out in ABS last week on my Monoprice Maker Select. I was able to get the hull printed out without much difficulty. I'll have to use a filler on the seem between the two hulls sections, but it looks really good. However the railgun barrel and the smaller "bits" on the turret came out way too fragile and broke apart easily. I may have to kitbash a new main gun and laser cannons to complete it. Still fantastic model. I always felt that Centurion should have been in 15mm rather than 6mm scale.
comments.author: siefertma

comments.text:
Hello,
Thanks for the feedback. Yes, the secondary weapons on the turret are very fragile. This was the first serious model I attempted and I was going for faithfulness to the drawings rather than simplifying the print.
There are a couple of things you could try to get them to print better if you wanted to. You could scale up the print by 1 or 2 percent in the slicer and see what difference that makes. You could also try slowing the print head speed down. I think I'm using 40mm/s for my print speed. I found that when the print head is laying down a new layer on a tall, thin round structure it drags the structure around with it. The end result can be somewhat of a drippy candle effect.
In any case, thanks for giving it a go! I have a couple of cohorts of these printed now and I think they will look great on the table.
Cheers, Dan
comments.author: siefertma

author: dcleyne

title: Drela AG14 Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (37.01g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
The propeller was designed after the Drela AG14 airfoil coordinates. All tests were performed on the Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig The results can be seen below.

It was printed at a slow speed, using a 0.2 extruder nozzle at 0.04 height per layer. The print was cleaned with an X-ACTO Knife

After this, I got to finishing the part using a 400 grit sandpaper.

These are the measurements for the 4 picked voltage values (you can also view these in the images taken during the test):

  • 1.5V => 12.34 grams
  • 2V => 23.45 grams
  • 2.5V => 29.47 grams
  • 3V => 37.01 grams

The included files contain all pictures relevant to the test, along with 6 txt files that contain airfoil coordinates, the printable STL files and finally the SLDPRT files. If you'd like to print this propeller, you should get a 8520 coreless motor.

You can use the SLDPRT extension files, should you wish to make your own changes to the drone propeller.

Notice: The airfoil plotted by using the matplotlib library in python.

title: Filter Holder for Tokina 16-28mm Lens - 150mm Glass

description.text:
150mm Filter Holder for the Tokina 16-28mm Lens - PLA

After 3 previous flaws in design (Too much vignetting at 16mm) I finalised with this one and based it on the 150mm glass. This design has NO vignetting at 16mm when testing without glass as I can't afford it just yet!

This design should be able to hold 3 x 150mm glass for whatever combination you need to achieve.

Please leave a comment if you print this and can test it with the 150mm glass! Also the spring plates are for 2mm thick glass and would also like to know if I got the side tension on the glass at a good sliding tightness or is it too loose?

The only extra things you need to buy is
6 x M3x15 countersunk screws (or like me you can just use standard heads!) to sandwich the springplates and topplate to the adapter
6 x M3 Nuts
1 x Self Adhesive Flexi-Seal 25mm wide by 4.5mm Thick - (From Bunnings https://www.bunnings.com.au/moroday-10m-flexi-seal-outdoor-seal-tape_p4114029) this is used as the cusioning between the printed surface and the lens fixed petal so you can easily slide the holder straight onto the lens but still making it a good tight fit.

****NOTE this type of seal has a very thin clear top layer almost like a clear tape which makes sliding the holder onto the lens very smooth without damaging the seal or the lens.

https://youtu.be/87lDF8LJGwk

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

12.5%

Notes:

Print the adapter with the large flange plate down and supports only needed under the 4 locating pins. I printed the tapered section with no issue with no supporting material

Also I Printed it all in PLA

Print
6 x SPRING PLATE V2
2 x SPRING PLATE TOP V2
1 x TOKINA ADAPTER-150mm

title: Minimalist Self watering Planter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Minimalistic self-watering planter work on a reservoir system. There is a water storage tank, at the bottom of the container, which you fill. There is an overflow hole, so excess water simply drains away. The soil soaks up the water from the bottom, so as long as you keep the reservoir filled, your plants get a consistent level of moisture, delivered directly to their roots.

  • Make sure you place some small rocks first before you place the soil, this will help keep the water storage tank at the bottom clean

author: BricoTechs

title: Bracket for mounting webcam to Mendel90 X-Motor

description.text:
A bracket for mounting a Microsoft LifeCam VX-800 to the x-motor of a Mendel90 3D-printer. By mounting the webcam to the x-motor the webcam will move up and down with the extruder unit along the printers z-axis.   
Note that the webcam is mounted upside down and the picture needs to rotated somehow.  
The files include the OpenSCAD sources. This allows to create remixes especially by reusing the bracket around the motor.  
The thing prints in one piece withount need for support.

I printed the thing on a Mendel90 in PLA with a layer height of 0.3 mm. Minimum layer time had to be increased to 30 seconds otherwise the overhang of the clamp for the ballhead would not print accurate enough.

author: UdayRaghuwanshi

description.text: Well I bought some Command Strips at the dollar store that came with two hooks and four strips. I said to myself, "This is inconvenient." So I made some more hooks.

"The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is the 2.0 version of our rage token, you need to print 12 to play our game. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

author: Myrmecoman

title: Inline Adapter for mini slide switch

description.text: In making the Minecraft torches ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:229421 ) I wanted a small, low-voltage, inline switch for the wall-wart cord. I couldn't find a suitable one so I made this inline adapter for the tiny slide switches common on battery-operated toys and lights. If anyone knows a source for these tiny switches, please post it. I reclaimed mine from the little "tea lights" that I used to build the Minecraft torch.

See gallery for size of switch and assembly. Tack it closed with a drop of cyanoacrylate or a touch of a soldering iron on the two top posts.  
The thru-holes barely fit the cord on the wall wart adapters I'm using, but if you have a thinner cord you might want to drop a little glue in just before you push the switch down into the housing, to provide a little more strain relief. This is a very minimalist design and there's not much room in there.  
Note that this is intended for the LOW VOLTAGE side of the adapter! There's no rating on the switches that I have, but I'm not going to use it over 12v and maybe 500mA.

comments.text: I believe that switch is called an SPDT slide switch. Here's one that's breadboard friendly https://www.adafruit.com/product/805

The part that attaches to the frame might require some very light sanding depending on your printer. Both sides are identical so just print 2 of the same part and flip it when attaching it.
